SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove too difficult to answer. If there is anything about your life which is special or outstanding, please feel free to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply to a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Western Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: East Ltd. Western Canadian Pioneer Butts" is still being circulated if you have not already answered it, and will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives hearts centre at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Board,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

A NOTE OF EXPLANATION TO THE PERSON ANSWERING THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether or not they are still living there.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Years," was distributed to all those who have not already answered it, and would be willing to do so.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

A brother came in 1891. Moved for his own plan then decided in Bowning.

For the Baptist Ministry

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

I remember one occasion in March 1916 when I was working on the road. The wind picked up and I started out on my way. When I got to work, I found a load of hay waiting for me. I loaded it onto my cart and continued on my way. As I worked, I noticed that the wind was getting stronger. I stopped and looked around, but I could not see anything. I turned back and tried to find my way home. It was dark and I could not see anything. I walked for what seemed like hours, but I could not find my way home. Finally, I gave up and decided to stay there until morning.
